localizedDescriptions.en: Interaction, contact or care event between a subject of care and healthcare provider(s).
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
The reason for initiation of any healthcare encounter or contact by the individual who is the subject of care.
Identification of the type, or administrative category, of healthcare sought or required by the subject of care.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Contact type' with a terminology is desirable, where possible. Examples include: pre-employment medical, routine antenatal visit, women's health check, pre-operative assessment, or annual medical check-up.

localizedDescriptions.en: The subjective clinical history of the subject of care as recorded directly by the subject, or reported to a clinician by the subject or a carer.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Narrative description of the story or clinical history for the subject of care.
Reported observation of a physical or mental disturbance in an individual.
The name of the reported symptom or sign.

annotations.comment: Symptom name should be coded with a terminology, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The identified symptom or sign was reported as not being present to any significant degree.

annotations.comment: Record as True if the subject of care has reported the symptom as not significant. For example: if the individual has never experienced the symptom it is appropriate to record 'nil significant'; or if the individual commonly experiences the symptom, in some circumstances it may be considered appropriate to record 'nil significant' if the individual has experienced no deviation from their 'normal' baseline.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the reported symptom or sign.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Details about a single identified health condition, injury, disability or any other issue which impacts on the physical, mental and/or social well-being of an individual.

annotations.comment: Clear delineation between the scope of a problem versus a diagnosis is not easy to achieve in practice. For the purposes of clinical documentation with this archetype, problem and diagnosis are regarded as a continuum, with increasing levels of detail and supportive evidence usually providing weight towards the label of 'diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of the problem or diagnosis, by name.

annotations.comment: Coding of the name of the problem or diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the problem or diagnosis.

annotations.comment: Use to provide background and context, including evolution, episodes or exacerbations, progress and any other relevant details, about the problem or diagnosis.

localizedDescriptions.en: Estimated or actual date/time the diagnosis or problem was recognised by a healthcare professional.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of clinical recognition" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: Estimated or actual date/time of resolution or remission for this problem or diagnosis, as determined by a healthcare professional.

annotations.comment: Partial dates are acceptable. If the subject of care is under the age of one year, then the complete date or a minimum of the month and year is necessary to enable accurate age calculations - for example, if used to drive decision support. Data captured/imported as "Age at time of resolution" should be converted to a date using the subject's date of birth.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date this problem or diagnosis was last updated.

An overall statement of exclusion about all Problems/diagnoses, Family history, Medications, Procedures, Adverse reactions or other clinical items that are either not currently present, or have not been present in the past.
Overall statement of exclusion of all problems or diagnoses at the time of recording.

annotations.comment: For example: 'No previous diagnoses', 'No known family history', 'No known history of adverse reactions', 'Never taken any medications' or 'No known operations or significant procedures'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Statement that specified health information is not available for inclusion in the health record or extract at the time of recording.
Positive statement that no information is available.

annotations.comment: For example: "No information available about adverse reactions"; No information available about problems or diagnoses"; "No information available about previous procedures performed"; or "No information available about medications used".

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the reason why there is no information available.

annotations.comment: For example: patient is unconscious or refuses to provide information. Coding the reason with a terminology is desirable, if possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date at which the absence was last updated.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
A clinical activity carried out for screening, investigative, diagnostic, curative, therapeutic, evaluative or palliative purposes.
Identification of the procedure by name.

annotations.comment: Coding of the specific procedure with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the procedure, as appropriate for the pathway step.

annotations.comment: For example: description about the performance and findings from the the procedure, the aborted attempt or the cancellation of the procedure.

localizedDescriptions.en: An overall statement of exclusion about all Problems/diagnoses, Family history, Medications, Procedures, Adverse reactions or other clinical items that are either not currently present, or have not been present in the past.
Overall statement of exclusion about all procedures at the time of recording.

annotations.comment: For example: 'No previous diagnoses', 'No known family history', 'No known history of adverse reactions', 'Never taken any medications' or 'No known operations or significant procedures'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Statement that specified health information is not available for inclusion in the health record or extract at the time of recording.
Positive statement that no information is available.

annotations.comment: For example: "No information available about adverse reactions"; No information available about problems or diagnoses"; "No information available about previous procedures performed"; or "No information available about medications used".

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the reason why there is no information available.

annotations.comment: For example: patient is unconscious or refuses to provide information. Coding the reason with a terminology is desirable, if possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date at which the absence was last updated.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Any activity related to the planning, scheduling, prescription management, dispensing, administration, cessation and other use of a medication, vaccine, nutritional product or other therapeutic item.

annotations.comment: This is not limited to activities performed based on medication orders from clinicians, but could also include for example taking over the counter medication.

localizedDescriptions.en: Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item which was the focus of the activity.

annotations.comment:
For example: 'Atenolol 100mg' or 'Tenormin tablets 100mg'. 
It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' is coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

localizedDescriptions.en: The combination of a medication amount and administration timing for a single day, in the context of a medication order or medication management.

annotations.comment: For example: '2 tablets at 6pm' or '20mg three times per day'. Please note: this cluster allows multiple occurrences to enable representation of a complete set of dose patterns for a single dose direction.

localizedDescriptions.en: Text description of the dose.

annotations.comment: For example: "Apply ointment to affected area until it glistens". This element is intended to allow implementers to use the structures for increasing/tapering dosages without necessarily specifying the doses in a structured way.

localizedDescriptions.en: An overall statement of exclusion about all Problems/diagnoses, Family history, Medications, Procedures, Adverse reactions or other clinical items that are either not currently present, or have not been present in the past.
Overall statement of exclusion about the use of all medications at the time of recording.

annotations.comment: For example: 'No previous diagnoses', 'No known family history', 'No known history of adverse reactions', 'Never taken any medications' or 'No known operations or significant procedures'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Statement that specified health information is not available for inclusion in the health record or extract at the time of recording.
Positive statement that no information is available.

annotations.comment: For example: "No information available about adverse reactions"; No information available about problems or diagnoses"; "No information available about previous procedures performed"; or "No information available about medications used".

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the reason why there is no information available.

annotations.comment: For example: patient is unconscious or refuses to provide information. Coding the reason with a terminology is desirable, if possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date at which the absence was last updated.
Suggested design pattern for including adverse reactions in a template.
Risk of harmful or undesirable physiological response which is unique to an individual and associated with exposure to a substance.

annotations.comment: Substances include, but are not limited to: a therapeutic substance administered correctly at an appropriate dosage for the individual; food; material derived from plants or animals; or venom from insect stings.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of a substance, or substance class, that is considered to put the individual at risk of an adverse reaction event.

annotations.comment: Both an individual substance and a substance class are valid entries in 'Substance'. A substance may be a compound of simpler substances, for example a medicinal product. If the value in 'Substance' is an individual substance, it may be duplicated in 'Specific substance'. It is strongly recommended that both 'Substance' and 'Specific substance' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. For example: Snomed CT, DM+D, RxNorm, NDFRT, ATC, New Zealand Universal List of Medicines and Australian Medicines Terminology. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

localizedDescriptions.en: Details about each adverse reaction event linked to exposure to the identified 'Substance'.
Identification of the substance considered to be responsible for the specific adverse reaction event.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Amoxycillin'. Only an individual substance is a valid entry in 'Specific substance'. A substance may be a compound of simpler substances, for example a medicinal product. If the value in 'Substance' is an individual substance and not a substance class, then it may be duplicated in this data element. It is strongly recommended that 'Specific substance' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible.  For example: RxNorm, Snomed CT, DM+D, NDFRT, ICD-9, ICD-10, UNI, ATC and CPT. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

localizedDescriptions.en: Clinical symptoms and/or signs that are observed or associated with the adverse reaction.

annotations.comment:
Manifestation can be expressed as a single word, phrase or brief description. For example: nausea, rash.  'No reaction'may be appropriate where a previous reaction has been noted but the reaction did not re-occur after further exposure. It is preferable that 'Manifestation' should be coded with a terminology, where possible. The values entered here may be used to display on an application screen as part of a list of adverse reactions, as recommended in the UK NHS CUI guidelines.



Terminologies commonly used include, but are not limited to, SNOMED-CT or ICD10.

localizedDescriptions.en: Date when the propensity or the reaction event was updated.

annotations.comment: Note: maps to recordedDate in FHIR.

localizedDescriptions.en: An overall statement of exclusion about all Problems/diagnoses, Family history, Medications, Procedures, Adverse reactions or other clinical items that are either not currently present, or have not been present in the past.

children.name: Global exclusion of adverse reactions

localizedDescriptions.en: Overall statement of exclusion about all adverse reactions at the time of recording.

annotations.comment: For example: 'No previous diagnoses', 'No known family history', 'No known history of adverse reactions', 'Never taken any medications' or 'No known operations or significant procedures'.

children.aqlPath: /content[openEHR-EHR-SECTION.adhoc.v1,'Past History']/items[openEHR-EHR-SECTION.adverse_reactions.v0,'Adverse reaction list']/items[openEHR-EHR-EVALUATION.exclusion_global.v1,'Exclusion - Adverse reactions']/data[at0001]/items[at0002,'Global exclusion of adverse reactions']/value

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional comment not covered in other fields.
Statement that specified health information is not available for inclusion in the health record or extract at the time of recording.
Positive statement that no information is available.

annotations.comment: For example: "No information available about adverse reactions"; No information available about problems or diagnoses"; "No information available about previous procedures performed"; or "No information available about medications used".

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the reason why there is no information available.

annotations.comment: For example: patient is unconscious or refuses to provide information. Coding the reason with a terminology is desirable, if possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date at which the absence was last updated.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Summary information about social circumstances or experiences that may have a potential impact on an individual's health.
Narrative description about social circumstances or experiences that may have a potential impact on an individual's health.

annotations.comment: May be used to record a narrative summary of the complete social circumstances or experiences or key aspects of the social summary, which will be supported by additional structured data, or to import textual data from existing/legacy clinical systems. Details of specific structured findings can be included using CLUSTER archetypes in the 'Details' slot.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date this social summary was last updated.
Summary or persistent information about an individual's current and past housing or accommodation situation.
Narrative description about the overall housing situation for the individual.
Details about the home environment of an individual.
Description of the home environment.
Source of water to the home or community.
Date when the housing summary or associated housing records was updated.
Summary or persistent information about an individual's current and past jobs and/or roles.
Statement about the individual's current employment.

annotations.comment: For example: employed; unemployed; or not in labour force. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible. Detail about each occupation can be recorded within the CLUSTER.occupation_record archetype.

localizedDescriptions.en: A single job or role carried out by an individual during a specified period of time.
The main job title or the role of the individual.

annotations.comment: For example: Chief Executive Officer; Carer; or Student. Each of these job titles or roles may be comprised of multiple duties.

localizedDescriptions.en: Date when the occupation summary or associated occupation records were was updated.

annotations.comment: At implementation, it is assumed that if an associated occupation record is added or updated then this date will also be updated.

localizedDescriptions.en: Summary or persistent information about an individual's current and past education or training.
Description of highest category of education or training completed.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible. For example: the ISCED classification, such as upper secondary vocational education; post-secondary non-tertiary vocational education; Bachelor’s or equivalent level, professional; Doctoral or equivalent level, academic; post-secondary non-tertiary vocational education; or never attended an educational program.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date that this education summary was last updated.

annotations.comment: At implementation, it is assumed that if an associated education record is added or updated then this date will also be updated.

localizedDescriptions.en: Group of individuals connected by social interactions and personal relationships.
Single word or phrase that describes  an individual's relationship with a significant other.

annotations.comment: Coding of the marital status with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: never married or single; married; divorced; or widowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Date when the summary was updated.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Summary or persistent information about the tobacco smoking habits of an individual.
Details about smoking activity for a specified type of smoked tobacco.
The type of tobacco smoked by the individual.
Also known as manufactured cigarettes, 'factory made' cigarettes or 'tailor made' cigarettes. Processed tobacco, manufactured into cylinder made of paper or a substance that does not contain tobacco.
Statement about current smoking behaviour for the specified type of tobacco.
Individual is a current smoker of the specified type of tobacco.
Individual has previously smoked the specified type of tobacco but is not a current smoker.
Individual has never smoked the specified type of tobacco.
Details about a discrete period of smoking activity for the specified type of tobacco.
Identification of an episode of smoking activity - either as a number in a sequence and/or a named event.

annotations.comment: For example: '2' as the second episode within a sequence of episodes; or 'Pregnancy with twins' if describing the smoking activity during a health event such as during a specific pregnancy.

localizedDescriptions.en: Estimate of number of units of the specified type of tobacco consumed.

annotations.comment: For example: the number of 'sticks' or 'full pipes' per day or per week. This data element is redundant if a value is recorded for 'Typical use(mass)'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date when the individual last ceased using tobacco of any type.

annotations.comment: Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. This date could be used by decision support guidance to determine if the  individual is at risk of relapse, for example in the first 12 months since quitting.

localizedDescriptions.en: Estimate of the cumulative amount for all types of tobacco smoked.

annotations.comment: The definition of a pack can be recorded in the protocol of this archetype using the 'Pack definition' data element.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about all tobacco smoking that has not been captured in other fields.

annotations.comment: For example: stopped smoking or reduced amount on becoming pregnant.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date this tobacco smoking summary was last updated.
Summary or persistent information about the typical alcohol consumption of an individual.
Details about a discrete period of time with a consistent pattern of typical consumption.
Statement about current alcohol drinking behaviour.
Individual consumed alcohol during this period.
Individual has not consumed alcohol during this episode.
Narrative summary about the individual's overall pattern of alcohol consumption during the specified episode.

annotations.comment: For example: details about binge drinking pattern.

localizedDescriptions.en: Identification of an episode of alcohol consumption - either as a number in a sequence and/or a named event.

annotations.comment: For example: '2' as the second episode within a sequence of episodes; or 'Pregnancy with twins' if describing the alcohol consumption during a health event such as during a specific pregnancy.

localizedDescriptions.en: The typical pattern of consumption of alcohol.

annotations.comment: The typical pattern of use can be made more granular by coding with a terminology or a local value set in a template.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date when the individual last ceased consuming alcohol of any type.

annotations.comment: Can be a partial date, for example, only a year. This date could be used by decision support guidance to determine if the individual is at risk of relapse, for example in the first 12 months since quitting.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about all alcohol consumption that has not been captured in other fields.
The date this alcohol consumption summary was last updated.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Summary information about the significant health-related problems found in family members.
Narrative overview about problems, diagnoses, psychosocial, environmental and genetic markers that have been identified in family members.

annotations.comment: This field can be used to record a summary or the conclusion of all the findings, for unstructured family history information recorded in clinical records, or to import textual data from existing/legacy clinical systems.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date this family history summary was last updated.

An overall statement of exclusion about all Problems/diagnoses, Family history, Medications, Procedures, Adverse reactions or other clinical items that are either not currently present, or have not been present in the past.
Overall statement of exclusion of all significant health-related problems in relatives or family members of the individual at the time of recording.

annotations.comment: For example: 'No previous diagnoses', 'No known family history', 'No known history of adverse reactions', 'Never taken any medications' or 'No known operations or significant procedures'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional comment not covered in other fields.
Statement that specified health information is not available for inclusion in the health record or extract at the time of recording.
Positive statement that no information is available.

annotations.comment: For example: "No information available about adverse reactions"; No information available about problems or diagnoses"; "No information available about previous procedures performed"; or "No information available about medications used".

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the reason why there is no information available.

annotations.comment: For example: patient is unconscious or refuses to provide information. Coding the reason with a terminology is desirable, if possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date at which the absence was last updated.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Measurement of the body weight of an individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The weight of the individual.
Height, or body length, is measured from crown of head to sole of foot.

annotations.comment: Height is measured with the individual in a standing position and body length in a recumbent position.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The length of the body from crown of head to sole of foot.
Calculated measurement which compares a person's weight and height.

annotations.comment: Body Mass Index is a calculated ratio describing how an individual's body weight relates to the weight that is regarded as normal, or desirable, for the individual's height.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Index describing ratio of weight to height.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the body mass index.

annotations.comment: For example: underweight, normal, overweight or obese.

localizedDescriptions.en: A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
The local measurement of arterial blood pressure which is a surrogate for arterial pressure in the systemic circulation.

annotations.comment: Most commonly, use of the term 'blood pressure' refers to measurement of brachial artery pressure in the upper arm.

localizedDescriptions.en: Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Peak systemic arterial blood pressure  - measured in systolic or contraction phase of the heart cycle.
Minimum systemic arterial blood pressure - measured in the diastolic or relaxation phase of the heart cycle.
The position of the individual at the time of measurement.
Standing at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Sitting (for example on bed or chair) at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Reclining at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Lying flat at the time of blood pressure measurement.
Simple body site where blood pressure was measured.
Method of measurement of blood pressure.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a stethoscope and Korotkoff sounds.
Method of measuring blood pressure externally, using a blood pressure machine.
Record details about the rate and associated attributes for a pulse or heart beat.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The pulse rate, measured in beats per minute.

annotations.comment: Run-time name constraints have been specified, in order to simplify the renaming of this data element to Pulse Rate or Heart Rate, as required.

localizedDescriptions.en: Is the pulse or heart beat regular?
The pattern is regular.
The pattern is irregular.
More specific pattern of an irregular pulse or heart beat.

annotations.comment: Selection of a value from this value set is only valid if 'Irregular' is selected from the 'Regularity' data element.

localizedDescriptions.en: The pattern is irregular in a regular pattern,. For example, a dropped beat once every 'n' beats.
The pattern is irregular in a chaotic and unpredictable manner. For example, atrial fibrillation.
Narrative description about the pulse or heart beat.
Specific conclusion about the rhythm of the pulse or heartbeat, drawn from a combination of the heart rate, pattern and other characteristics observed on examination.

annotations.comment: Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible. For example: Bradycardia, Extrasystoles or Sinus rhythm. Multiple statements are allowed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Method used to observe the pulse or heart beat.

annotations.comment: For example, auscultation or electronic monitoring.

localizedDescriptions.en: The findings are observed by physical touch of the observer on the subject.
The findings are observed non-invasively using a device such as a pulse oximeter or a stethoscope.
A measurement of the body temperature, which is a surrogate for the core body temperature of the individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The measured body temperature (as a surrogate for the core of the body).
Blood oxygen and related measurements, measured by pulse oximetry or pulse CO-oximetry.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
The saturation of oxygen in the peripheral blood, measured via pulse oximetry.

annotations.comment: SpO₂ is defined as the percentage of oxyhaemoglobin (HbO₂) to the total concentration of haemoglobin (HbO₂ + deoxyhaemoglobin) in peripheral blood.

localizedDescriptions.en: The amount of oxygen being delivered, or to be delivered, to the patient given as a fraction, percentage or indirectly as a flow rate.
Oxygen flow rate given to an individual.

annotations.comment: For example '5 l/min'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The patient is receiving air, equivalent to 21% O₂ or 0.21 FiO₂ and an oxygen flow rate of 0 litres per minute.

annotations.comment: Where 'On air' is set to true, Flow rate, FiO₂ and Percent O₂ should not be recorded. Conversely 'On air' should be omitted if Flow rate, FiO₂ or Percent O₂ are recorded.

localizedDescriptions.en: The method used to deliver the oxygen.

annotations.comment: Intended to capture only simple description / terms, for example: 'nasal prongs'. The 'Oxygen delivery detail' slot may be used for more detailed or complex recording.

localizedDescriptions.en: The observed characteristics of spontaneous breathing as would commonly be recorded as part of a 'vital signs' examination.
Generic event.
Rate of respiration.
Rhythm of respiration.
Regular respiration.
Irregular respirations.
A text description of respirations.
Respiratory pattern or single word, phrase or brief description which represents the clinical meaning and significance of the measurements.
Deep chest breathing with or without a visible gasp.
Periods of hyperventilation alternating with periods of apnoea.
Breathing of varying tidal volumes and rates.
Deep, gasping inspiration with a pause at full inspiration followed by a brief, insufficient release of breath.
Clusters of irregular breaths that alternate with periods of apnoea. Also termed Biot's breathing.
Breathing has ceased.
The respiratory expiratory phase is longer than normal/usual. Associated with obstructive airways disease such as asthma.
Abnormally rapid breathing.
Abnormally slow breathing.
Normal breathing pattern.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Findings observed during the physical examination of a subject of care.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Findings observed during the physical examination of the respiratory system as a whole.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The respiratory system was examined.
Statement that no abnormality was detected (NAD) on physical examination.

annotations.comment: Record as True if no abnormality was detected on examination. Specific statements about the examination can be included in the 'Clinical Interpretation' data element. If 'No abnormality detected' is selected, then recording of other examination data elements becomes redundant, with the exception of only the 'Clinical interpretation' data element, which may be useful if a normal statement is desired for recording, for example 'Normal examination'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
Findings observed during the physical examination of a single lung, including specific parts of a lung.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The left lung was examined.
The right lung was examined.
Identification of the area of the body under examination.

annotations.comment: If the body site has been fully identified in the 'System or structure examined' data element, this data element becomes redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: Statement that no abnormality was detected (NAD) on physical examination.

annotations.comment: Record as True if no abnormality was detected on examination. Specific statements about the examination can be included in the 'Clinical Interpretation' data element. If 'No abnormality detected' is selected, then recording of other examination data elements becomes redundant, with the exception of only the 'Clinical interpretation' data element, which may be useful if a normal statement is desired for recording, for example 'Normal examination'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
Sound elicited by tapping on the chest wall.
Percussion note was normal.
Percussion note was flat or dulled.
Percussion note was louder and lower pitched than normal.
Vibration intensity heard by a stethoscope on the chest wall with certain spoken words.
Vocal resonance was normal.
Vocal resonance was increased, compared to normal.
Vocal resonance was decreased, compared to normal.
Vibration intensity felt by the hand on the chest wall from certain spoken words.
Vocal fremitus was normal.
Vocal fremitus was increased, compared to normal.
Vocal fremitus was decreased, compared to normal.
Findings observed during the auscultation of breath sounds in the chest or abdomen.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The chest is examined.
The abdomen is examined.
Statement that the breath sounds were heard and of normal character.

annotations.comment: Record as True if no abnormality was detected on examination. Specific statements about the examination can be included in the 'Clinical Interpretation' data element. If 'No abnormality detected' is selected, then recording of other examination data elements becomes redundant, with the exception of only the 'Clinical interpretation' data element, which may be useful if a normal statement is desired for recording, for example 'Normal examination'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
Details about abnormal breath sounds heard on auscultation.
Name of the breath sound.
Whistling noises produced in the airways during breathing. Also referred to as rhonchi.
Clicking, rattling or crackling noises produced in the airways during breathing. Also referred to as crepitations.
Phase of the breathing cycle.
On inspiration only.
On expiration only.
On both inspiration and expiration.
Presence of the abnormal breath sound.
The abnormal breath sound is present.
The abnormal breath sound is not present.
Narrative description about the abnormal breath sound.
Findings observed during the physical examination of the cardiovascular system as a whole.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The cardiovascular system was examined.
Statement that no abnormality was detected (NAD) on physical examination.

annotations.comment: Record as True if no abnormality was detected on examination. Specific statements about the examination can be included in the 'Clinical Interpretation' data element. If 'No abnormality detected' is selected, then recording of other examination data elements becomes redundant, with the exception of only the 'Clinical interpretation' data element, which may be useful if a normal statement is desired for recording, for example 'Normal examination'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
Findings observed during the physical examination of the heart.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The heart was examined.
Statement that no abnormality was detected (NAD) on physical examination.

annotations.comment: Record as True if no abnormality was detected on examination. Specific statements about the examination can be included in the 'Clinical Interpretation' data element. If 'No abnormality detected' is selected, then recording of other examination data elements becomes redundant, with the exception of only the 'Clinical interpretation' data element, which may be useful if a normal statement is desired for recording, for example 'Normal examination'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
An excess of watery fluid collecting in the cavities or tissues of the body.
Narrative description of the oedema findings observed during the physical examination.
Estimation of the severity of oedema.
No oedema is present.
The oedema is mild.
The oedema is moderate.
The oedema is severe.
The nature of the oedema.
Pitting of the skin on finger pressure.
No pitting of the skin on finger pressure.
Findings observed during the physical examination of the abdomen.
Identification of the examined body system or anatomical structure.

annotations.comment: For example: the very generic term "skin", which will likely require additional qualification using one of the 'Body site' data elements, or the complete phrase "skin of right knee". Coding of the system or structure examined with a terminology is preferred, where possible.

localizedDescriptions.en: The part of the body containing the digestive and reproductive organs.
Statement that no abnormality was detected (NAD) on physical examination.

annotations.comment: Record as True if no abnormality was detected on examination. Specific statements about the examination can be included in the 'Clinical Interpretation' data element. If 'No abnormality detected' is selected, then recording of other examination data elements becomes redundant, with the exception of only the 'Clinical interpretation' data element, which may be useful if a normal statement is desired for recording, for example 'Normal skin examination'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description of the overall findings observed during the physical examination.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Any activity related to the planning, scheduling, prescription management, dispensing, administration, cessation and other use of a medication, vaccine, nutritional product or other therapeutic item.

annotations.comment: This is not limited to activities performed based on medication orders from clinicians, but could also include for example taking over the counter medication.

localizedDescriptions.en: Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item which was the focus of the activity.

annotations.comment:
For example: 'Atenolol 100mg' or 'Tenormin tablets 100mg'. 
It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' is coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

localizedDescriptions.en: A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
The result, including findings and the laboratory's interpretation, of an investigation performed on specimens collected from an individual or related to that individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Name of the laboratory investigation performed on the specimen(s).

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. It is strongly recommended that 'Test name' be coded with a terminology, for example LOINC or SNOMED CT. For example: 'Glucose', 'Urea and Electrolytes', 'Swab', 'Cortisol (am)', 'Potassium in perspiration' or 'Melanoma histopathology'. The name may sometimes include specimen type and patient state, for example 'Fasting blood glucose' or include other information, as 'Potassium (PNA blood gas)'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
The intended position of this analyte result within the overall sequence of analyte results.

annotations.comment: For example: ''1' '2', '3'. Where multiple analyte results are reported, the 'Analyte result sequence' makes the order in which they were reported explicit.

localizedDescriptions.en: The name of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: The value for this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte. For example: 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. Coding with an external terminology is strongly recommended, such as LOINC, NPU, SNOMED CT, or local lab terminologies.

localizedDescriptions.en: The value of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: For example '7.3 mmol/l', 'Raised'. The 'Any' data type will need to be constrained to an appropriate data type in a specialisation, a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte result. The Quantity data type has reference model attributes that include flags for normal/abnormal, reference ranges and approximations - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_quantity_class for more details.
annotations.hl7v2_mapping: OBX.2, OBX.5, OBX.6, OBX.7, OBX.8;OBX.2, OBX.5, OBX.6, OBX.7, OBX.8

localizedDescriptions.en: The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.
Narrative description of the key findings.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Pattern suggests significant renal impairment'. The content of the conclusion will vary, depending on the investigation performed. This conclusion should be aligned with the coded 'Test diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: This indicates whether the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT) as opposed to a formal result from a laboratory or other service delivery organisation.

annotations.comment: True if the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT).

localizedDescriptions.en: Qualitative and semi-quantitative test array using reagent test strips to indicate possible abnormalities in a sample of urine, often performed as part of Point of Care Testing (POCT).
A specific date and/or time which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Detection of glucose in urine sample.
No glucose detected.
Amount equivalent to 1/10 g/dl (100mg/dL or 5 mmol/L) detected.
Amount equivalent to 1/4 g/dL (250 mg/dL or 15 mmol/L) detected.
Amount equivalent to 1/2 g/dl (500mg/dL or 30 mmol/L) detected.
Amount equivalent to 1 g/dl (1000mg/dL or 60 mmol/L) detected.
Amount equivalent >2 g/dl (>2000mg/dL or >120 mmol/L) detected.
Detection of protein in urine sample.
No protein detected.
Trace of protein detected.
Amount equivalent to 30mg/dL (or 0.3 g/L) detected.
Amount equivalent to 100mg/dL (or 1.0 g/L) detected.
Amount equivalent to 300mg/dL (or 3.0 g/L) detected.
Amount equivalent to >2000mg/dL (or >20 g/L) detected.
Positive statement to record that a physical examination or clinical test was not performed.
Statement to explicity record that the examination was not performed.

annotations.comment: Record as True if the examination was not performed.

localizedDescriptions.en: Reason for the 'not done' statement.

annotations.comment: For example: patient factors, equipment factors, time constraints.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result, including findings and the laboratory's interpretation, of an investigation performed on specimens collected from an individual or related to that individual.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Name of the laboratory investigation performed on the specimen(s).

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. It is strongly recommended that 'Test name' be coded with a terminology, for example LOINC or SNOMED CT. For example: 'Glucose', 'Urea and Electrolytes', 'Swab', 'Cortisol (am)', 'Potassium in perspiration' or 'Melanoma histopathology'. The name may sometimes include specimen type and patient state, for example 'Fasting blood glucose' or include other information, as 'Potassium (PNA blood gas)'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
The name of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: The value for this element is normally supplied in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte. For example: 'Serum sodium', 'Haemoglobin'. Coding with an external terminology is strongly recommended, such as LOINC, NPU, SNOMED CT, or local lab terminologies.

localizedDescriptions.en: The value of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: For example '7.3 mmol/l', 'Raised'. The 'Any' data type will need to be constrained to an appropriate data type in a specialisation, a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte result. The Quantity data type has reference model attributes that include flags for normal/abnormal, reference ranges and approximations - see https://specifications.openehr.org/releases/RM/latest/data_types.html#_dv_quantity_class for more details.

The value of the analyte result.
The value of the analyte result.

The value of the analyte result.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Pattern suggests significant renal impairment'. The content of the conclusion will vary, depending on the investigation performed. This conclusion should be aligned with the coded 'Test diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: This indicates whether the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT) as opposed to a formal result from a laboratory or other service delivery organisation.

annotations.comment: True if the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT).

Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.

annotations.comment: A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. The value of the analyte result.

Narrative description of the key findings.

annotations.comment: For example: 'Pattern suggests significant renal impairment'. The content of the conclusion will vary, depending on the investigation performed. This conclusion should be aligned with the coded 'Test diagnosis'.

localizedDescriptions.en: This indicates whether the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT) as opposed to a formal result from a laboratory or other service delivery organisation.

annotations.comment: True if the test was performed directly at Point-of-Care (POCT).

localizedDescriptions.en: A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Communication to improve health literacy and life skills.
Identification of the topic of health education, by name.

annotations.comment: The 'Topic' could identify a single piece of information or a single skill, or it may be the name of a training course or program that may be delivered over multiple sessions or visits. The name may indicate that the education was transferred to a group or the individual.

localizedDescriptions.en: A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
A generic section header which should be renamed in a template to suit a specific clinical context.
Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.
Current Activity.
The name of the single service or activity requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

localizedDescriptions.en: Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.
Current Activity.
The name of the single service or activity requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

localizedDescriptions.en: An order for a medication, vaccine, nutritional product or other therapeutic item for an identified individual.
Details of the requested order.
Name of the medication, vaccine or other therapeutic/prescribable item being ordered.

annotations.comment: Depending on the prescribing context this field could be used for either generic- or product-based prescribing. This data field can be used to record tightly bound orders of different medications when they are prescribed as a single pack. It is strongly recommended that the 'Medication item' be coded with a terminology capable of triggering decision support, where possible. The extent of coding may vary from the simple name of the medication item through to structured details about the actual medication pack to be used. Free text entry should only be used if there is no appropriate terminology available.

localizedDescriptions.en: The route by which the ordered item is to be administered into the subject's body.

annotations.comment:
For example: 'oral', 'intravenous', or 'topical'.
Coding of the route with a terminology is preferred, where possible. Multiple potential routes may be specified.

localizedDescriptions.en: Complete narrative description about how the ordered item is to be used.

annotations.comment: This narrative should normally subsume data captured in 'Dose amount', 'Dose timing' and any additional instructions for use. Where the medication dose directions are fully carried by the structured, computable dose directions, this element should carry the narrative equivalent, generally auto-generated. If it is not possible to represent the intended 'Dose direction' fully in computable form, partial representation is not recommended, and the directions should be only recorded in narrative form using this data element.

localizedDescriptions.en: An additional instruction directed primarily at the individual/patient or carers.

annotations.comment: For example: 'To reduce your blood pressure', 'To thin your blood'. This data element allows multiple occurrences and should be coded with a reference terminology, where possible. If required it is possible to use a LINK attribute to associate this element with, for example, the 'original diagnosis' in a separate Problem list composition but the indication should be explicitly recorded here, as the link target may change over time.

localizedDescriptions.en: Additional narrative about the medication order not captured in other fields.
To demonstrate a design pattern for representation Referral details within a Referral composition.
Request for a health-related service or activity to be delivered by a clinician, organisation or agency.
Current Activity.
The name of the single service or activity requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service name' with a coding system is desirable, if available. For example: 'referral' to an endocrinologist for diabetes management.

localizedDescriptions.en: Category of service requested.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Service type' with a coding system is desirable, if available. If the 'Service name' was coded, it is possible for this data point to be derived from the code. For example: biochemistry or microbiology laboratory, ultrasound or CT imaging.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the service requested.

annotations.comment: This data point should be used to describe the named service in more detail, including how it should be delivered, patient concerns and issues that might be encountered in delivering the service.

localizedDescriptions.en: A short phrase describing the reason for the request.

annotations.comment: Coding of the 'Reason for request' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required. For example: 'manage diabetes complications'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Narrative description about the reason for request.

annotations.comment: For example: 'The patient's diabetes has recently become more difficult to stabilise and renal function is deteriorating'.

localizedDescriptions.en: The clinical reason for the ordered service.

annotations.comment: Coding of the clinical indication with a terminology is preferred, where possible. This data element allows multiple occurrences. For example: 'Angina' or 'Type 1 Diabetes mellitus'.

localizedDescriptions.en: Description of the intent for the request.

annotations.comment: For example: a referral to a specialist may have the intent of the specialist taking over responsibility for care of the patient, or it may be to provide a second opinion on treatment options. Coding of the 'Intent' with a coding system is desirable, if available. This data element allows multiple occurrences to enable the user to record a multiple responses, if required.

localizedDescriptions.en: Urgency of the request for service.

annotations.comment: Specific definitions of emergency and urgent will vary between clinical contexts, clinical systems and the nature of the request itself, so have not been defined in this archetype. If explicit timing is required then the Service period should be clearly stated.

localizedDescriptions.en: The request requires immediate attention.
The request requires prioritised attention.
The request does not require prioritised scheduling.
The date/time, or acceptable interval of date/time, for provision of the service.

annotations.comment: This data element allows for recording of the timing for a single service, either as a date and time, a date ranges or a text descriptor which can allow for 'next available. In practice, clinicians will often think in terms of ordering services as approximate timing, for example: review in 3 months, 6 months or 12 months. As clinical systems need more exact parameters to operate on, this '3 months' will usually be converted to an exact date 3 months from the date of recording and stored using this data element. If complex timing or sequences of timings are required, use the CLUSTER.service_direction archetype within the 'Complex timing' SLOT and this data element becomes redundant.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date/time, or acceptable interval of date/time, for provision of the service.
The date/time, or acceptable interval of date/time, for provision of the service.
The date/time, or acceptable interval of date/time, for provision of the service.
The date/time that marks the beginning of the valid period of time for delivery of this service.

annotations.comment: This date/time is the equivalent to the earliest possible date for service delivery. For example: sometimes a certain amount of time must pass before a service can be performed, for example some procedures can only be performed once the patient has stopped taking medications for a specific amount of time.

localizedDescriptions.en: The date/time that marks the conclusion of the clinically valid period of time for delivery of this service.

annotations.comment: This date/time is the equivalent to the latest possible date for service delivery or to the date of expiry for this request. For example: a service may be required to be completed before another event, such as scheduled surgery.

localizedDescriptions.en: The valid period for this request is open ended and has no date of expiry.

annotations.comment: Record as TRUE to record explicity that the request has no expiry date. For example: commonly required for a referral to a specialist for long-term or lifelong care.

localizedDescriptions.en: Supplementary information will be following request.

annotations.comment: Record as TRUE if additional information has been identified and will be forwarded when available. For example: pending test results.

localizedDescriptions.en: Description of the supplementary information.
Additional narrative about the service request not captured in other fields.
The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.

annotations.comment: Usually equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
The local identifier assigned to the request by the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.

annotations.comment: Usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.

localizedDescriptions.en: The local identifier assigned to the request by the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.
The local identifier assigned to the request by the clinician or organisation receiving the request for service.
The status of the request for service as indicated by the requester.

annotations.comment: Status is used to denote whether this is the initial request, or a follow-up request to change or provide supplementary information. Coding with a terminology is preferred, where possible.
